	<generator>http://wordpress.org/?v=3.5.1</generator>

	<item>
		<title>Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 11 Sep 2012 05:30:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=149</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm on a mission to learn to code. In 18 weeks time, I'll transform myself from a non-technical person into an entry level developer.

In the past, I've learned bits and pieces of various languages (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Ruby) in my "<em>spare time</em>", but it just doesn't produce noticeable results. I did learn the basics, but with no real depth of understanding. Instead, if I want to obtain a deeper understanding and proficiency of programming, I need to devote myself fulltime to learn code, which requires that I reduce my other commitments. So why am I doing this?

[caption id="attachment_154" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Kings-Game.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-154 " title="King's Game" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Kings-Game-300x225.jpg" alt="Chess Game" width="300" height="225" /></a> Photo courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/colemama/3942606430/">colemama</a>[/caption]

This is <strong>not</strong> based on typical career motivations where my focus is to simply get more education and training in order to improve my long term job outlook. My background is in working with technology startups, but never as part of the technical team. My role has always been on the marketing and operations end.

I founded <a href="http://facethebuzz.com/blog">Face The Buzz</a> so that I could work with many amazing web and mobile technology startup companies. I've been extremely fortunate to work with so many great entrepreneurs. Starting this company has been an amazing learning experience and has increased my appetite for starting more companies in the future. But, I also want to be part of the early stage development and building of a product. This step can not be accomplished without a much stronger technical understanding on my part.
<h2>Send a Tweet to Support Me</h2>
<code>I support @andrewkkirk on his journey to go from total noob to #programmer in 18 weeks.</code>
<a href="http://clicktotweet.com/uAbCx" target="_blank">&lt; Tweet This Message &gt;</a>

I'm documenting the entire process in hopes that it can help someone else in my position who wants to undertake a similar journey, but doesn't have clue about where to begin. If you have questions, please share them in the comments. I'm also sharing my thoughts in hopes that millions of talented developers our there can provide me feedback and guidance. If you have suggestions on programming, learning, startups, or any other interesting topic, please do share it in the comments.

That's why I'm planning to teach myself and hopefully successfully invest time, energy, and resources in learning these new skills. But, I'm not doing it completely alone. If you're reading this, I'll need your help as well. Leave your questions or words of encouragement in the comments below. Thanks!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[I'm on a mission to learn to code. In 18 weeks time, I'll transform myself from a non-technical person into an entry level developer. So why am I doing this?]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>My Plan to Learn Code</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/plan-learn-code/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 Sep 2012 03:35:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=198</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We each have our own learning styles. Because I don't have an engineering or computer science background, I'm hoping my that previous learning experiences will be applicable enough to this new undertaking to learn code.
<h2>Learning Styles</h2>
I <strong>learn by doing</strong>. I've previously tried to pick up programming books which were formatted like an academic textbook - an introductory chapter, followed by 10-15 chapters, each on a specific topic. I didn't become engaged in the material.

With learning a foreign topic, I need to feel like I'm hitting the ground and running. Even if in reality I'm moving at a slow walk, I still need to feel the movement of progress underneath me.

<img class="alignright size-full wp-image-201" style="border: 2px solid grey;" title="Rails for Zombies Redux Code School" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Rails-for-Zombies-Redux-Code-School-e1347592803553.png" alt="Rails for Zombies Redux Code School" width="200" height="200" />

Therefore, tutorials and online lessons will be the bread and butter of my first three weeks. I especially enjoy interactive micro-lessons, where each step involves learning a new concept followed directly with user application. For Ruby, I'll be using <a title="Code School" href="http://www.codeschool.com/courses" target="_blank">Code School</a> (Rails for Zombies, Git Real). For HTML, CSS, JavaScrip, and jQuery, I really like <a title="Codecademy" href="http://www.codecademy.com" target="_blank">Codecademy</a>.
<h2>Project Based to Learn Code</h2>
I have <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/">18 weeks</a> and I know that I can't simply spend the entire time following other's tutorials or lessons. Starting with week 10, the halfway point in my process, I'll start working on a web app project of my own. I imagine I would quickly become mentally fatigued without diving into a project of my own undertaking.

This important step, will serve as a transition between simple repetition and more <strong>critical thinking</strong>. Also, I've selected an app for which my interest will help to motivate and drive forward my learning. I'll be writing more about the project (and looking for testers!) as the time approaches. The app functionality isn't a secret, I just don't want to get too far ahead of myself by discussing it at this point.

And don't think that I have any irrational expectation that my first app will be a runaway success. My excitement is driven by the possibility of building something useful and interesting.

And if it happens to make a billion dollars, well, that's just an added bonus. :)

Understanding personal learning style is a critical step in learning anything. Do you learn best by doing, listening, reading, or something else? How would you improve my plan? Leave your thoughts and comments below.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[I've given myself 18 weeks to learn to code. This plan is one key to my success. ]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>198</wp:post_id>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2012-09-14 13:58:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hey Andrew,  I really like http://ruby.railstutorial.org/ruby-on-rails-tutorial-book 
it has helped make a ton of sense out of Rails, Git and Heroku. Previously I tried diving in on a friend's project which was a big mistake.  Also I'm working through the best workflow for front end design -&gt; front end code for Rails projects as that is what I would likely do on a app, not the back end. Fireworks and Dreamweaver actually look like good places to start for design first projects.  If they are code first, design later then it seems nice to take a live generated page and strip everything but the app data, write the front end code, and merge it into the rails app.  Still not sure if this is the best way. But the amount of time burned setting up postgres and rails just right fro a complex app seems to take longer than getting out a few good working coded designs.

Hope all is well out West. Getting ready for another Indy Startup Weekend in November.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Lots of great insight. I'd love to hear more from your perspective. 



1. I've heard many people praise Michael Hart's Rails Tutorial. I previously completed the first 6 chapters. I felt like I was plugging away, but not getting a feel for the big picture. I think I'll do a few basic, high-level lessons and then jump back into it. Did you have previous technical experience before trying it?


2. Why was working on a friend's project a mistake? Do you try to take on too much, did your interest in someone else's project wain, or another reason? 


3. My plan (as of now) is to first complete the front end code without design, and then merge design back into the rails app. 

So great to such helpful comments from you. Best of luck with SW Indy; I'll be following online!]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_author_IP>128.210.66.222</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2012-10-01 10:07:00</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2012-10-01 17:07:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hey Andrew, sorry for the delay.  
1. I have technical experience, but no exposure to Rails before this project. I am more of a front end guy (CSS3, HTML5, javascript). I only used it so far up through chapter 5 or so with the bootstrap integration, since my goal was to do the front end of a friend's project.
2. the problem is since you can code in your own fashion it was hard to compare what he did to what the best practice tutorials say you should do.  so i ended up with a lot of head scratching and digging around.  i got too confused.  so i would do the tutorials with a new app from scratch so you can follow along. it makes it a lot easier to troubleshoot the code and build a foundation.
3. yeah it seems like a lot of people code first, then pretty it up. I think that is OK, as long as you have wireframe mockups with real content first. then code it to function, then put the design back in.  

]]></wp:comment_content>

It's true that I could possibly not accomplish all my goals that I've set out to reach, but that wouldn't be a failure. In fact, there would be a lot learned and gained in the process, regardless of outcome, simply by undertaking such an adventurous project.]]></wp:comment_content>

		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>3 Steps to Create The Ultimate Plan to Learn Code</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/3-steps-create-plan-learn-code/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 18 Sep 2012 00:30:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=247</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[There is an amazing <strong>wealth of information</strong> available to anyone wishing to learn code. This abundance of resources is both assuring and overwhelming. How do you sift through available resources and choose the course of learning best for you?

The nature of learning a new skill requires that you dive into foreign territory, which can be scary. But, it's not uncharted territory; there are others who have been in your shoes before and succeeded.

For me, I visualize learning a skill as trying to cross from one side of a giant river to the other side. You're currently on one side and you want to get to the other side. Standing, gazing across that great divide, you know there are lots of people who have tried to cross and have been unsuccessful. But, there also people who have crossed successfully, doing so using various methods available to you.

[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="500"]<a title="River crossing by MShades, on Flickr" href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/mshades/154086367/"><img src="http://farm1.staticflickr.com/46/154086367_dfce21bc98.jpg" alt="River Crossing" width="500" height="276" /></a> Photo courtesy of <a href=" http://www.flickr.com/photos/mshades/154086367/"> Chris Gladis</a>[/caption]
<p style="text-align: left;">How do you, standing alone on the starting side, determine which path is <strong>right for you</strong>? Following these 3 steps will help.</p>

<h2>#1 Evaluate All Options Against Your Resources</h2>
There are many options out there - too many to list. Quora is a great resource for any language you're trying to learn. Here's the <a href="http://www.quora.com/Ruby-programming-language/How-do-I-learn-Ruby" target="_blank">Quora question and answer</a> I used for as guide for Ruby. Because most resources will either be online or books available to order, create a bookmark folder for each language to save your list.

Also, your resources factor heavily into your decision as well. For me, spending years to get a CS degree, attending a developer bootcamp, or hiring a private tutor wasn't an option because of time and cost reasons. <strong>Eliminate any options</strong> for which you don't have the resources.
<h2>#2 Determine Your Learning Style and Match Resources</h2>
Once you've got a list of resources, it's time to evaluate those options against your own learning style. Just because someone raved about a learning source doesn't mean it's right for you. Remember, there are many people who successfully crossed the river, but they didn't all take the same journey. Find what <strong>works best</strong> for your brain.
<h2>#3 Don't Be Afraid To Iterate</h2>
This last step is crucial, especially in learning web development. If you find a resource isn't holding your attention or is incredibly too hard or too easy, don't allocate your precious resources on it. Get rid of it and move on. This isn't school, you're not being graded on what you complete; instead, your accomplishment is all about what you learn.

One <strong>word of warning</strong>, don't quit a resource because it's challenging you; some of the best learning happens at this neural point.

My first week was scheduled to include Michael Hartl's Ruby Tutorial. I even had a <a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/plan-learn-code/#comment-650331514" target="_blank">comment</a> posted, which suggested this tutorial was a good place to start. However, I ultimately shifted course and focused my time on Rails for Zombies by <a title="Code School" href="http://www.codeschool.com/" target="_blank">Code School</a>. I wanted to see the individual Rails pieces in action (<strong>MVC</strong>) before diving in heads first.
<h2>Learn Code Conclusion</h2>
Your <strong>time is the most precious resource</strong> you have when learning a new skill. Do what's best for you and be able to adjust your plan as needed.

How do you create a plan for learning a new skill? Leave your thoughts and comments below.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[There is a wealth of information available to anyone wishing to learn code. How do you choose the best course for you? Follow these 3 simple steps. ]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>dsq_thread_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[848490258]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>63</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[brian ball]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email></wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://twitter.com/brianball</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>75.61.64.101</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2012-12-10 02:01:00</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2012-12-10 10:01:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hi Andrew,

Nice write up: here's my iteration:

&gt;#1 Evaluate All Options Against Your Resources
&gt;#2 Determine Your Learning Style and Match Resources
&gt;#3 Don’t Be Afraid To Iterate



If you're going to do step #2 anyway, why not do it first. If you know you don't learn well on your own, why consider books, videos, etc. when a coach, tutor, or in-class instructor with a lab component is your route to go. Same for being an auditory learner or visual etc.


Once you get a feel for the route you want to take, there are dozens of places to start. I'd say pick 3 and spend a few minutes in each. Look for good reviews because reviewers saying what worked for them can give good insight.


Iterate for sure. As you learn a bit and get more info, you should definitely try to build something. Coding is like writing. If you don't know why you're writing, you won't be able to say anything. Without wanting a solution to a problem, your code learning won't stick.


Any coding practice that's heavy on typing and practice is probably better than that which is heavy on theory. For Ruby, using IRB to type something in and get that instant feedback is required to get your brain to connect "code" to output.


Keep going. I like your Project &gt;&gt; Next Feature development cycle.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>dsq_parent_post_id</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>dsq_post_id</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[732145174]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>65</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Andrew K Kirk]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>andrew.k.kirk@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://andrewkkirk.com/</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>75.85.53.62</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2012-12-10 10:53:00</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2012-12-10 18:53:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[@twitter-7305822:disqus - You present a great point, there probably isn't a value in considering learning tools/options that don't match your style of learning. 


Great comment!]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>63</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>dsq_parent_post_id</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[732145174]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>dsq_post_id</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[732519693]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>4 Factors Crucial for Choosing Your First Programming Language</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/4-factors-choose-first-programming-language/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Sep 2012 06:52:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=263</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In creating my <a title="My Plan to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/plan-learn-code/">plan to learn to code</a>, I made the decision to learn <strong>Ruby</strong>. The first programming language is a very important decision and one that I didn't take lightly. Below is the process I followed to make this decision.

First, a bit about <strong>web technologies</strong> (<em>you can skip to the 4 factors if you're familiar with web technologies</em> <a href="#anchor-1">click here</a>). If you're like me, someone without a technical background, you've been amazed by a first-hand experience with an amazing web application.

While that amazing web app is a <strong>cohesive product</strong>, it's important to understand that there are several layers or tiers of functionality you're experiencing simultaneously. Before you choose your area of study, consider how each of these areas apply to you.
<h2>Tiers of Web Functionality</h2>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Graphic Designer</strong> - This person creates the visual aesthetics of an app, including colors, logo, and layout. The graphic design determines the immediate impact felt by users and the mood conveyed by a site. Graphic design isn't truly a web development tier, but I think it's important to recognize because of its impact on users.</li>
	<li><strong>Web Designer</strong> - Using primarily HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, the web designer brings a web app to life and makes it interactive to the end user.</li>
	<li><strong>Web Applications Developer</strong> - This developer is concerned with the interaction between the client (web browser) and the application server.</li>
	<li><strong>Web Database Developer</strong> - In complement to applications developer, the web database developer ensures a smooth connection between the application server and the database.</li>
</ul>
<a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Web-Browser-App-Server-and-Database-Diagram.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-269" title="Web Browser, App Server, and Database Diagram" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Web-Browser-App-Server-and-Database-Diagram.png" alt="Web Browser, App Server, and Database Diagram" width="405" height="538" /></a><a name="anchor-1"></a>

Experts in each of these areas work collaboratively to execute a complete web application. In reality, most everyone learns skills across different tiers and it's not practical to dedicate yourself to learning only one area in a vacuum separate of any others. But, you do need to select your <strong>primary area of expertise</strong> and that should the focus of your first programming language. This level of specificity will ensure you have a clear end goal and focus of study.

Once you've selected your tier of expertise, you need to select a specific language. Just like there are different spoken langues to express "<em>Hello</em>", there are different tools and languages within your chosen area, each with pros and cons. I won't start to name all the specific options, but instead show how you can evaluate these options and pick what programming language is right for you.

I selected the <strong>Web Applications Developer</strong> tier and then narrowed my language choices to python, PHP, and Ruby. Here is the process I used to evaluate different languages and decide where to start.
<h2>4 Factors for Learn to Code</h2>
<h3><strong>#1 Executing a Prototype</strong></h3>
<strong></strong>You want to learn because you want to build something which serves a purpose. Your first development attempt will not bring you fame and fortune. But, you may build a prototype which either inspires someone else to work with you or to invest in your idea. How easily you can build this basic mode is a strong factor to consider.

Learning programming is a means to an end objective and getting outside support can expedite your process. Because Ruby has the Rails framework, I felt confident I'll be able to get up a working prototype by <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/">the end of my 18 weeks</a>.
<h3><strong>#2 Learning Feedback</strong></h3>
<strong></strong>I'm part of the ADD generation. Our brains have been trained to expect immediate gratification. If you're learning and there is large barrier to begin executing, it's going to make the process more tedious. If you have the dedication, then more power to you. Be realistic about your expectations and commitment to your goal.
<strong></strong>
<h3><strong>#3 Access to Mentorship</strong></h3>
<strong></strong>Don't underestimate this factor. There are unlimited resources avaiable online and in books, but the talking with someone one-on-one is a huge help. Use meetup groups locally where you can meet web developers in your selected language. Developers were in you're shoes once, and most are willing to help you. Even better, find mentor-specific opportunities to get involved with.

I was lucky to get connected with <a href="https://twitter.com/tara" target="_blank">Tara Tiger Brown</a> in Los Angeles and the <a href="http://teachmestuff.net/about/" target="_blank">Teach My Stuff</a> program. Through this program, I'm working with <a href="https://twitter.com/bostonsteamer" target="_blank">Joe Goldberg</a>, who's Ruby expertise helped me plan my own learning program. We meet every two weeks and he's available to answer questions when I need clarifying.
<strong></strong>
<h3><strong>#4 Future Relevance</strong></h3>
<strong></strong>While not as important factor as the first three, it is still worth considering. Web development changes rapidly and you wouldn't want to bank on what's going to happen in the future. You should consider your future opportunities, both from a career standpoint and the type of projects you'll be suited to work on.

For example, there are many people who have a passion for Latin and thus choose to learn what's considered a "dead language". But, your future opportunities if you learn a programming language that's the equivalent of Latin will be diminished.
<h2>Conclusion</h2>
These are the factors which I considered when choosing Ruby. Do you agree or disagree with my reasoning? Are there factors that I didn't include, which should be considered? Leave your thoughts and questions in the comments.

<strong>Update:</strong> Join the lobste.rs discussion <a href="https://lobste.rs/s/etkk7o/4_factors_crucial_for_choosing_your_first_programming_language" target="_blank">here</a>.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Your first programming language is a very important decision. Show you how to evaluate and pick what programming language is right for you.]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Yeah, I had experience with basic C on a hobby basis so I already knew some basic programming principles.

About people picking their first language, I think the web design for the sites about the various languages can have impact. I don't remember where, but I read a blog about more and more designers getting into specific programming languages enabling more visual goodness for libraries and code they engage in.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>28</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>dsq_parent_post_id</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[697960671]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>dsq_post_id</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[698156889]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>68</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Sayth Renshaw]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>flebber.crue@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://profiles.google.com/flebber.crue</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>58.168.3.236</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2012-12-12 02:38:00</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2012-12-12 10:38:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I came to the same outcome, I actually tried a little Ruby and a little Python before deciding.

Took into account several different factors:

1. Library assets and their communities: Numpy, iPython, nice access to R. 

2. I wanted my applications to be data driven and feature numerical analysis. As well as the strong libraries their would be more non programming assistance available. So assistance from those well versed in maths and analysis who use python as a tool not as their primary focus.

3. My ability to contribute to others - I felt that with linux especially I could commit and assist others committing code, learning to code while helping others, join communities and learn more as a whole. Example every linux distribution ships with python by default and most rely on python e.g Fedora installer is in Python, Ubuntu actively promotes PyQT for its app stores and ships a ready development environment.



4. There isn't too much difference in outcome between using Django vs Rails. If I know one I can always change and use the other later the learning will be beneficial either way.


As stated at the start I tried both before deciding,just enough to get a taste. I liked both so in some way it didn't help. 


I actually based my main decision on somewhat non language specific features such as resources, communities, contribution and a perception I could achieve better numerical analysis with python.


PS I am aware of the new in development SciRuby team and their grant from matz to develop numerical libraries.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>13</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>dsq_parent_post_id</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[661449747]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>dsq_post_id</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[733808051]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>69</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Andrew K Kirk]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>andrew.k.kirk@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://andrewkkirk.com/</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>75.85.53.62</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2012-12-12 13:53:00</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2012-12-12 21:53:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Trying each language isn't a bad idea. Anyone serious about developing will pick up additional languages so it can't hurt to be exposed to a few early one.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>68</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>dsq_parent_post_id</wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The Power of Group Learning to Code</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/power-developers-group-learning-to-code/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 29 Sep 2012 16:48:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=281</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I was in San Diego this week and a friend invited me to attend a <a href="http://www.sdtig.com/" target="_blank">San Diego Tech Immersion Group (SDTIG)</a> meeting. It's experienced computer programmers who want to learn new technical skills.  I was struck by the unique group learning to code environment being fostered by the group.

The group consists of 3 developer leaders/mentors and approximately 100 developer participants, who follow a new learning track every six months. The Fall 2012 track is focused on web development (HTML/HTML5, CSS, Javascript, JSON, and JQuery). Monthly, each member completes the same reading assignment from a book for the current technology and the topics are discussed in a more detail during monthly meetings.

Here are few amazing features of this group learning:
<h2>Learners Helping Learners</h2>
Members help each other overcome stumbling blocks while learning new technology. In addition to the monthly meetings, there is a forum for group discussion. Because each person is going through the same track, there's great opportunity for collaborative learning, members jump in to help when they understand the material.
<h2>Expert Mentors as Guides</h2>
These mentors serve as an expert resource for the group. More than just subject-matter expertise, these mentors also plan the learning schedules, select the materials, and determine an appropriate learning pace.

Learning isn't easy and creating <a title="3 Steps to Create The Ultimate Plan to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/3-steps-create-plan-learn-code/">a plan to learn</a> a foreign subject is a challenge. These experts greatly reduce that burden.
<h2>Social Pressure = Accountability</h2>
This aspect was never directly mentioned during the meeting, but I couldn't help notice it. There's no financial cost to join the group, but by actively choosing to participate in a group environment, there is a social force at play. You don't want to fall behind so you complete the reading and come prepared to discuss.
<h2>Conclusion</h2>
I'm always on the lookout for new and interesting resources for <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/" target="_blank">learning to code</a>. The SDTIG was a new experience and not like anything I've come across locally (<em>if you know of something similar in LA, let me know</em>).

There are characteristics of a traditional classroom setting, but there is much more collaboration amongst the members. Also, members complete individual learning, but it is in a structured, expert-guided fashion. This mix and match of learning styles, guidance, and support are great for beginners learning to code.

<span style="font-size: x-small;">featured image courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/ubclibrary/2702156266/" target="_blank">UBC Library</a> </span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Group learning provides 3 factors which help to create a unique and helpful environment for learning to code. ]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Learning to Code Progress - 3 Weeks Completed</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/learning-to-code-progress-3-weeks/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Oct 2012 17:01:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=290</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm now three weeks or 1/6 into my learning to code process and my progress to date can be summed up in one word: <strong>slow</strong>

[caption id="attachment_297" align="aligncenter" width="472"]<a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/slow.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-297" title="slow" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/slow.jpg" alt="slow moving" width="472" height="266" /></a> Photo courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/freefoto/2231356418/">Ian Britton</a>[/caption]

Alright that's probably being a little harsh on myself. But, when I first started out this process, I thought I could be plugging away and building something after three weeks.

Instead, my time has been spent completing lessons and Ruby on Rails tutorials, but I'm not yet to the point where I feel I could begin building a project or web app on my own. That's a frustrating current state because I have ideas that I want to <strong>execute</strong>.
<h2>Maintaining Perspective</h2>
I'm staying positive and my <a title="Teach Me Stuff" href="http://teachmestuff.net/about/" target="_blank">Teach Me Stuff</a> mentor, <a href="https://twitter.com/bostonsteamer" target="_blank">Joe Goldberg</a>, is very helpful in this area. Here's a snippet of our reacent phone conversation discussing my progress:
<blockquote><strong>Me:</strong> <em>"I feel that I'm learning, but it's going much slower than I imagined at the onset."</em>

<strong>Joe:</strong> <em>"I'd be surprised if you told me any different."</em></blockquote>
It's incredible how<strong> reassuring</strong> it was for me to hear this simple phrase. Learning to code is foreign territory to me and I have no point of reference by which to judge my progress. On the other hand, Joe is experienced with Ruby and development. This support is a large benefit of having a <strong>web development mentor</strong>.
<h2>Adjustments Moving Forward</h2>
I'm not planning any major changes. However, one very important takeaway for me has been the idea that I need to focus more specifically on learning Rails, a framework for building with Ruby, than Ruby itself.  My focus for this 18 weeks needs to be moving to where I can build a product. As a result, my comprehension of Ruby will, understandably, not be as strong.

In the future, I may have to backtrack or dive further into Ruby because I've missed something in this first 18 weeks. That's a short-term sacrifice that seems reasonable. I don't want a preoccupation with learning every facet of Ruby to hinder my ability to create an app.

Leave your thoughts about my progress, focusing more a Rails, or any other thoughts in the comments below. Also, for those interested, here are the specific tutorials and lessons I've completed to date.
<h3>Completed</h3>
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.codeschool.com/courses" target="_blank">Code School Try Git</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.codeschool.com/courses" target="_blank">Code School Rails for Zombies</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://teamtreehouse.com/library" target="_blank">Treehouse Ruby Foundations</a> lessons (<em>partial</em>)</li>
	<li><a href="http://teamtreehouse.com/library" target="_blank">Treehouse Build a Simple Ruby on Rails App</a> (<em>partial</em>)</li>
	<li><a href="http://rubysource.com/" target="_blank">Rubysource Rails Deep Dive</a> (<em>in progress</em>)</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Learning to code progress after 3 weeks, including maintaining perspective and making adjustments moving forward. ]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Why It&#039;s Important to Learn How Developers Work</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/how-developers-work/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 06 Oct 2012 23:35:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=303</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The focus of my <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/">learning to code project</a> has been on improving my understanding of Ruby and building an app with the help of Rails. Until, this week I hadn't given much thought about how developers work, especially in a team environment.

That changed recently when I attended <a href="http://www.carbonfive.com/" target="_blank">Carbon Five</a> bimonthly <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Hack-Night-at-Carbon-Five-LA/" target="_blank">Hack Night</a>. Twice a month, this developer shop opens it doors to all and invites people in to work on their own personal projects.

<a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/logo_carbonfive.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-306" title="logo carbonfive" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/logo_carbonfive.png" alt="logo carbonfive" width="200" height="67" /></a>

It's an informal setting, and I took the opportunity to work part way through <a href="https://twitter.com/danielkehoe" target="_blank">Daniel Kehoe's</a> <a href="http://railsapps.github.com/">RailsApps Project</a>. Two hours into the evening, Travis, a Carbon Five developer, and I struck up a conversation. We spent very little time talking specific code or functionality and instead discussed how developers work. As a recent convert from .NET to Ruby, he provided some great insight.

Travis and I discussed many aspects of developing in a team and here are 3 most important I came away with.
<h2>#1 Pair Programming</h2>
The concept that two people would stand together at one computer working simultaneously blew my mind. Upon hearing this idea, it immediately contradicted how I would imagine you best use developer resources.

But, Travis described to me several scenarios where he and another developer at the onset didn't individually know how to accomplish the task at hand, but were able to harness pair programming to drive though a development sprint. Working as a duo, these two could accomplish more than either could working separately. This multiplicative effect in efficiency is an incredible result.

In addition to the project benefits, pair programming helps you <strong>learn new concepts</strong> and become familiar with the <strong>techniques and style</strong> of your coworkers.

Travis even offered to pair program with me when I feel ready. I can only begin to imagine the learning benefits to be gained of working side-by-side an experienced developer.
<h2>#2 Like-Minded, Not Like-Skilled Coworkers</h2>
I want to be a developer who is constantly learning new skills. This mentality seems particularly important with web development where the programming languages change rapidly. To learn from other developers requires finding others who have a different skill set.

But while the skills are different, it seems important to share similar philosophies for development practices. For instance, it would be difficult to learn from another developer if your attitudes on testing differ greatly. And I'm sure there other characteristics which are important to consider. I'm interested to pick up more insight around this thought process as I progress.
<h2>#3 Test Driven Development</h2>
The upfront investment in writing tests before coding pays off dividends in the long run. Specific to Ruby, I inquired Travis' thoughts on Test::Unit vs. Rspec. He suggested I understand at least the basics of Test::Unit. I'm interested to get more feedback on learning testing.

As a new developer, I've heard the importance of testing. But, I'm not so much inspired to to learn testing as I a feel it's an obligation of the trade. I want to learn it sufficiently to build web apps that don't break. If that means I can use Rspec without diving into Test::Unit, I'm all for it.
<h2>How Developers Work Conclusion</h2>
As with any environment, there is not a "correct" way by which all developer teams should operate by. Being introduced to the concepts was extremely important and I'd recommend all new developers be introduced to it early in the learning cycle. Use Meetups focused specifically on programming (not networking events), or if that's not an option, ask a more experienced developer directly if you can spend a few hours observing an informal work session.

Share your thoughts in the comments section.

<span style="font-size: x-small;">featured image courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/elmastudio/6840128061/" target="_blank">elmastudio</a></span>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How I Measure My Progress to Learn to Code</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/how-measure-learn-to-code-progress/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Oct 2012 22:52:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=316</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Taking the plunge to go full-time to learn to code was exhilarating. I knew what I wanted to accomplish and began laying out a <a title="My Plan to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/plan-learn-code/">project plan</a>.

I also knew it would be important to measure my progress along the way. I definitely didn't want to simply throw up my hands after 18 weeks and shout "Ta-Da!"

Receiving this Tweet from @mdbenner prompted me to write out specifically how I'm measuring my progress.
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet tw-align-center" data-in-reply-to="256568086591844354">@<a href="https://twitter.com/andrewkkirk">andrewkkirk</a> btw... how are you going to measure your transformation from noob to <a href="https://twitter.com/search/%23programmer">#programmer</a> ?... <a href="https://twitter.com/search/%23metrics">#metrics</a>

— mdbrenner (@mdbrenner) <a href="https://twitter.com/mdbrenner/status/256748996431859712" data-datetime="2012-10-12T13:31:45+00:00">October 12, 2012</a></blockquote><style>.twt-reply{display:none;}</style>
<h2>Think About The End First</h2>
In order to track my progress, I had to have an end goal by which to gauge. I struggled with coming up with a specific, tangible achievement goal.

My initial thought was to base it on finding a short, contract job as a developer. My rationale was that if someone else believed in my abilities enough to hire me, then this was validation enough that I'd achieved a certain level of knowledge and understanding.

After much thought and consideration, I abandoned the "job goal" for two reasons. First, my decision to learn to code is not motivated by finding a job or improving my career opportunities. I'm going down this path because I want to be able to build and execute interesting products. Thus, making my success dependent on a job felt counterintuitive.

Second, I sought out input from talented developers and tech people that I admired. Several, especially <a href="https://twitter.com/tara" target="_blank">Tara Brown</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/busterbenson" target="_blank">Buster Benson</a>, helped me realize that if I made the job the end goal, then this outcome would influence me and my plan. It would be easy to make decision about languages, tools, and platforms based off an employment motivation; ultimately, I didn't want unnecessary external influence finding it's way into my plan.

At this point, I took a step back and realized I was making it too complicated. If my goal is to increase my technical skills to build a product, then it makes sense to create a product as the end goal.
<blockquote>If you're inexperienced, create goals based on learning the code necessary to build a product. <a href="http://clicktotweet.com/16Q2e" target="_blank">&lt;Tweet This&gt;</a></blockquote>
Obviously I couldn't build a product from day one. So, I've divided the 18 weeks into two halves. In the first 9 weeks, my focus is on completing as many tutorials as possible, reading <a href="http://guides.rubyonrails.org/" target="_blank">Ruby on Rails Guides</a>, and getting familiar with developer basics, such as RubyGems, Bundler, Rake, and version control (Git). The second 9 weeks will be dedicated to a project-based learning style, where I'll be learning by building.
<h2>Learn to Code Tracking Progress</h2>
I do track my progress and what I've completed. For one I want to keep myself honest and ensure I'm completing ample work each week. Second, I want to have a record of the work I've completed.

I use <a href="http://pivotaltracker.com" target="_blank">Pivotal Tracker</a> to record each tutorial or lesson I complete. Using Agile development mentality, tutorials and lessons are logged as "<a href="http://www.jamesshore.com/Agile-Book/stories.html" target="_blank">stories</a>". I score each story as either 1,2,4, or 8 points based on difficulty and time required to complete. I also log my time for each story, in order to understand how long a story took to complete.

<em><strong>Note:</strong> I'm not Agile nor Pivotal Tracker expert; I simply adopted these systems in a manner to meet my own needs.</em>

<a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/Learn-to-Code-Pivotal-Tracker.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-328" title="Learn to Code - Pivotal Tracker" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/Learn-to-Code-Pivotal-Tracker.png" alt="Pivotal Tracker" width="355" height="246" /></a>

My hope is that I complete as much or more points each week. However, I'm mindful not focus too much on simply churning out stories each week. If a tutorial isn't helpful, I'm not afraid to abandon it before completing it. These aren't homework assignments; my focus is on learning. Therefore, I try to balance the importance of completing a steady pace of work each week, with ensuring that my time is dedicated to learning.

How do you track progress on your goals? Share your thoughts in the comments section.

<span style="font-size: x-small;">Featured image courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/aussiegall/286709039/" target="_blank">Louise Docker</a>.</span>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Bianca - That's awesome! For me, I needed a tangible end goal and timeframe in which to complete it. Without these contraints, it would be too easy to slow down and give myself too much leeway in terms of completing the necessary steps. 

For me to be successful in anything, I set goals which have:

1) a very specific end result (avoid generalities)
2) exact timeframes 

Good luck!]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>

				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[713052707]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>3 Tips for Asking for Help Learning to Program </title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/3-tips-help-learning-to-program/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 23 Oct 2012 01:50:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=358</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Learning to program is not easy, especially in my case coming from a non-technical, non-engineering background. The biggest boost to my entire process has been finding help directly from other people. In the age of the internet, you might think that all answers are already available online and we could simply cut out the human-to-human interaction.
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Wrong!</strong></p>
If you're looking for answers to simple questions or to very specific error messages, then a simple web search will be your best bet. But, in my experience, the ability to speak and work directly through difficult problems with another person, is the area where the greatest learning takes place.

The most difficult aspect is finding and seeking out the help. People won't randomly stop by your blog or Facebook page, to ask if you have questions. You have to take a very proactive approach to learning from others. This step can be intimidating for many people. When you're in the position of having less knowledge and asking for a favor for someone with greater knowledge, it can be scary.

There's no need to be scared. Here's the biggest lesson I've learned throughout this entire project:
<blockquote>When learning to program, most developers are happy to help - you just have to ask. <a href="http://clicktotweet.com/W11D8" target="_blank">&lt; Tweet This&gt;</a></blockquote>
With that mentality in mind, here are three tips to find the right people to ask and get help learning to program.
<h2>#1 Send a Tweet Asking for Help</h2>
Tweet to a specific person and not just out into the entire twittersphere. This method is great for people who've created online teaching tools. Twitter is a public forum and your question will bring exposure to their project. For example, I was working on the '<a href="http://rubysource.com/free-rails-deep-dive-ebook/" target="_blank">Rails Deep Dive</a>' from RubySource, and had questions so I went directly to the owner <a href="https://twitter.com/ruprictGeek" target="_blank">Glen Goodrich</a>.
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet tw-align-center" data-in-reply-to="251063781457809408">@<a href="https://twitter.com/ruprictgeek">ruprictgeek</a> Can't get past the"rails g rspec:install" step on page 31. Unfamiliar with MonogoDB. StackOverflow no help. Suggestions?

— Andrew K Kirk (@andrewkkirk) <a href="https://twitter.com/andrewkkirk/status/251453688827219969" data-datetime="2012-09-27T22:50:05+00:00">September 27, 2012</a></blockquote>
&nbsp;

He responded directly to my question and created a <a href="https://gist.github.com/3815755" target="_blank">gist</a> on GithHub with a detailed explanation to my questions. Unprompted, he sent a message directly to <a href="https://twitter.com/rails_apps" target="_blank">Daniel Kehoe</a> informing him about my self-guided <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/" target="_blank">learning to program project</a>. Daniel reached out to me directly to let me know about his <a href="http://railsapps.github.com/" target="_blank">RailsApps Project</a>, which is geared towards getting a new Rails project up and running very quickly. Daniel's built an incredible resource for developers, and he's also been extremely responsive and helpful to me. Keep in mind this entire chain of events with Glen and Daniel was kicked off by me sending a Tweet to a complete stranger. Isn't the internet incredible?
<h2>#2 Find Online Communities</h2>
For specific technical questions, StackOverflow or IRC channels will likely be more helpful. However, to find help for the purpose of learning, you need to find individuals who'll take a more personal interest in your progress. The best method to accomplish this scenario is to look for online communities specific to your language, where people develop relationships and look out for one another. Use<strong> <a href="https://groups.google.com" target="_blank">Google Groups</a></strong> are online communities with a very specific focus. Search and you'll find people talking about your language, answer questions, and providing guidance. <strong>Find Helper Hotlines</strong> I was overjoyed when I first discovered the <a href="http://rails.pockethotline.com/" target="_blank">Rails Hotline</a>. The concept is that more experienced Ruby on Rails developers hold tutoring hours online, where students can call them directly. Unfortunately, my experience has been a miss to date. I've tried calling twice without a response.
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet tw-align-center" data-in-reply-to="252902169920028672">@<a href="https://twitter.com/andrewkkirk">andrewkkirk</a> Sorry just saw your message. We’re averaging about 50% on answering calls, so don’t let a missed connection get you down. — Rails Hotline (@railshotline) <a href="https://twitter.com/railshotline/status/260200785986596865" data-datetime="2012-10-22T02:07:56+00:00">October 22, 2012</a></blockquote>
<script charset="utf-8" type="text/javascript" src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js"></script>
But, that recent Tweet gives me hope that I'll have better luck the next time I try. It is a free service, with donations excepted, so my expectations are tempered at this moment.
<h2>#3 Find Local Developers</h2>
Use meetup.com to find groups dedicated to the language you're learning. There will be free meetings and you'll learn from experts. But, the meetings can happen in several different formats, all of which can be helpful to meeting developers.

<strong>Social Gatherings</strong>

While you won't be opening up your laptop to learn, social gatherings are a great place to meet lots of developers and find interesting projects that others are working on. The more developers you know the better. They may help you learn, introduce you to other developers, and perhaps help you get a job one day.

In Souther California, <a href="http://www.latechhappyhour.com/" target="_blank">LA Tech Happy Hour</a> and <a href="http://www.meetup.com/106MilesSoCal/" target="_blank">106 Miles - Southern California</a> are a good <strong>Social Gathering</strong> meetup.

<strong>Tech Presentations</strong>

Presentations by other developers are a great way to learn, especially about new technologies or techniques. For total newbies, they are probably too advanced, but you can still meet people. The networking time will be limited as compared to Social Gatherings.

In LA, <a href="http://www.meetup.com/laruby/" target="_blank">LA Ruby on Rails Monthly Meetup</a> is a great monthly Ruby <strong>Tech Presentations</strong> meetup.

<strong>Hack Nights</strong>

These are my favorite meetups, especially for learning. The basic concept is that everyone gets together to work individually on projects. These meetings are great for finding more advance developers to sit down with you in front of your project and work in tandem. Your brain will be stimulated during these sessions in ways you couldn't have imagined.

In LA, <a title="Why It’s Important to Learn How Developers Work" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/how-developers-work/" target="_blank">Carbon Five Hack Nights</a> has been amazing!

Regardless of the meetup type, you should always have genuine interesting in meeting and talking to developers. It will help you grow your network and you'll likely find people willing to help. Do NOT go to meetings and start conversations by telling people you're looking for a developer coach or tutor. You'll appear insincere and will quickly scare away anyone from helping you.

Instead, show an interesting in getting to know the group members. Better yet, prior to your first meeting, contact the group organizer. Explain to him/her that you're new, excited to get involved, and offer to help. By taking an interest the in the group, others will take an interest in you and your projects.
<h2>Help Learning to Program Conclusion</h2>
Help is available in many different forms. Never be afraid or embarrassed to ask for assistance. Most developers love to help for two reasons. First, people love appearing knowledgeable and sharing knowledge with others is an ego boost. Second, at some point in time, the developer was in the exact same shoes as you and can commiserate with the process you're going through. This sense of shared experience instantly creates a bond between you, the learner, and the experienced developer.

<span style="font-size: x-small;">Featured Image courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kandyjaxx/2012468692/">K Nicoll</a></span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Learning to program is not easy. The biggest boost to my entire process has been finding help directly from other people. The ability to speak and work directly through difficult problems with another person, is the area where the greatest learning takes place. When learning to code, most developers are happy to help - you just have to ask.  With that mentality in mind, here are three tips to find the right people to ask and get help learning to program.]]></excerpt:encoded>

A lot of the programs I use seem to run PHP, so that was my initial thought. Then I hear javascript is the easiest to learn and think it may be best to start with. After you study languages &amp; frameworks for a while, they all start to look similar. It's the same with spoken languages too: French, Italian, &amp; Spanish are all somewhat similar, and you can communicate virtually the same messages with them all. Just pick the one you like and run with it :)]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>27</wp:comment_parent>

				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[702147751]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Learning to Program and When to Start Building Your Own App?</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/11/learning-to-program-start-build-your-own-app/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 03 Nov 2012 23:14:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=409</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[After completing 8 weeks, I have hit a critical point in my <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/">learning to program journey</a> - I've begun coding my first app. I feel a new excitement because this is what I've been working towards for almost 2 months now. But, how did I arrive at the point where I was comfortable enough to start programming my own app?

<strong><a href="http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=tl%3Bdr" target="_blank">tl;dr</a>: </strong>I didn't feel comfortable. I felt nervous and unsure of my abilities. But, to make my learning process more targeted, I needed a project to direct what to learn next.
<h2>Where's My 'Aha' Moment?</h2>
<blockquote>If we wait until we’re ready, we’ll be waiting for the rest of our lives. <strong>-Lemony Snicket <a href="http://clicktotweet.com/cf5_9" target="_blank">&lt; </a></strong><a href="http://clicktotweet.com/cf5_9" target="_blank">Tweet This<strong>&gt;</strong></a></blockquote>
Remember those standardized tests we took throughout elementary and middle school in which we proved our arithmetic and reading comprehension was sufficient to move us on to the next grade? There's no equivalent competency test in computer programming (<em>at least that I'm aware of</em>). So what did I use to evaluate my own proficiency, in that I had acquired the necessary foundation to begin programming on my own?

Here's the funny part - there was never a moment when I hit a particular milestone or understood "enough" technique that told me I was ready to begin building. Interestingly, it was more a specific moment at which I felt continuing the tutorials and intro lesson were no longer beneficial.

It occurred to me while reading about cookies and storing sessions in Action Controller in the <a title="Rails Guides" href="http://guides.rubyonrails.org/" target="_blank">Rails Guides</a>. At that moment, it struck me; how can I understand the impact of cookies with no frame of reference? I realized I'd hit the point where I needed to build an application in order to guide what is relevant for me to learn.

Additionally, my mentor through this process assured me that I'd never get to a point where I felt perfectly comfortable building on my own. Part of learning to program adventure is diving into unknown territory.
<h2>Hitting Highs and Lows</h2>
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="320"]<a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/tea-cups.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-420  " title="tea cups" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/tea-cups.jpg" alt="tea cups dizzy" width="320" height="213" /></a> My brain starting to program. Photo courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/andycastro/3979817018/">Andy Castro</a>.[/caption]

Starting on my first project was a rush. This euphoria was quickly followed by the realization of how lost I am. Staring at a blank project made my brain feel like it had been on the tea cups ride at DisneyLand.

But these mini-panic moments are actually helpful. Hitting a moment when I don't know how to move the app forward, are actually learning opportunities (<em>disguised as error messages</em>) literally popping up on my screen.

With my foundation from 8 weeks of tutorials, I've built a simple app. Each step in the app's functionality that I can't execute sends me a quest for answers. Using StackOverflow, blogs, and Twitter, I've <a title="3 Tips for Asking for Help Learning to Program" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/3-tips-help-learning-to-program/" target="_blank">found help</a> and overcome obstacles.

This is the essence of project-based learning. Rinse and repeat this <strong>break-learn-build</strong> process a few hundred times and I'll have built a functional web app while learning Ruby.

At least, that's the plan.

<strong>Update:</strong> Join the discussion thread on <a href="https://lobste.rs/s/mycvzo/learning_to_program_and_when_to_start_building_your_own_app" target="_blank">Lobste.rs</a>

<span style="font-size: x-small;"> Featured image courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rishibando/4682030797/">Rishi Bandopadhay</a></span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[After completing 8 weeks, I have hit a critical point in my learning to program journey - I've begun coding my first app. But, how did I arrive at the point where I was comfortable enough to start programming my own app?]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Rogues Ruby Nuby Project Video </title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/ruby-nuby-project-video/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 31 Oct 2012 21:38:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=412</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The team at Ruby Rogues is putting together a show, Ruby Nuby Project, based on learning Ruby. They've requested Ruby noobs, like myself, to submit a video describing their experience. You can see my video and written response below. Here are the specifics of the request: 

<blockquote>Have your Nuby record a 5 minute video talking about their experience learning Ruby. They should answer these questions:
<ul>
	<li>Who are you?</li>
	<li>What do you use Ruby for?</li>
	<li>How have you gone about learning the language? What resources did you use? E.g. books, videos, blog posts, online courses, one-on-one tutoring, etc.</li>
	<li>What has been the most difficult, surprising and/or delightful aspect of learning Ruby?</li>
	<li>What do you appreciate most about the Ruby community?</li>
</ul>
</blockquote>
Here is why I'm learning to program Ruby. 
<iframe width="480" height="360" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/1xV7ik1WAkU?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
<h2>Who are you?</h2>
I’m an entrepreneur, digital marketer, and founder of the digital marketing agency <a href="http://facethebuzz.com/" target="_blank">Face The Buzz</a>. I’m on a mission to learn to code. I’m dedicating myself <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/" target="_blank">full-time for 18 weeks</a> to transform myself from a non-technical person into a beginning programmer. I'm 7 weeks into journey so far and having a blast.
<h2>What do you use Ruby for?</h2>
I don’t have an engineering or computer science background. I'm learning Ruby so I can use it to develop web apps. My background is in working with technology startups, but never as part of the technical team. My role has always been in marketing. I’ve been extremely fortunate to work with many great entrepreneurs. I want to be part of the early stage development and building of a product.
<h2>How have you gone about learning the language? What resources did you use? E.g. books, videos, blog posts, online courses, one-on-one tutoring, etc.</h2>
I learn by doing. Therefore, I've focused on online tutorials. I've used a <a href="http://andrewkkirk.com/about" target="_blank">few online courses</a>, including Code School's Rails for Zombies, Treehouse, Codecademy for HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. I'm also using a project based approach to learn to program and I've begun to work on a web app project of my own. This important step and I hope will help me transition between simple repetition into more critical thinking about programming.
<h2>What has been the most difficult, surprising and/or delightful aspect of learning Ruby?</h2>
Ruby and Rails have an amazing amount of functionality built into the language/framework. This feature is powerful, but can also be difficult and confusing for trying to understand exactly what's going on inside an app.
<h2>What do you appreciate most about the Ruby community?</h2>
I appreciate how receptive and helpful the Ruby community is. Whether it's sending out a tweet, using online communities, or a meetup, developers have been very friendly and <a title="3 Tips for Asking for Help Learning to Program" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/3-tips-help-learning-to-program/">happy to help</a> - you just have to ask.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[The team at Ruby Rogues is putting together a show, Ruby Nuby Project, based on learning Ruby. Here is why I'm learning to program Ruby. ]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The Role of Stress in Learning to Program</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/11/stress-learning-to-program/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Nov 2012 15:43:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=423</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm a pretty upbeat, positive person. I really believe we make a choice each day of whether to be happy or not. And I make decisions according to this belief. It was this philosophy that sent me on a <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/">journey learning to program</a>.

During this process, I've maintained a similar attitude, and I've tried to convey this attitude in my posts. The sentiment is not artificial; I'm learning a ton, meeting some <a title="Why It’s Important to Learn How Developers Work" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/how-developers-work/">amazing people</a>, and having a great time. But that certainly doesn't mean I don't feel stress nor anxiety.
<h2>Outcome Importance in Learning to Program</h2>
I'm headed down unfamiliar territory and that generates fear and uncertainty. Now that I've <a title="Learning to Program and When to Start Building Your Own App?" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/11/learning-to-program-start-build-your-own-app/">transitioned to building my own app</a>, there's an added sense of responsibility. The real work has begun and I'm feeling the pressure.

I worry about building something that will be public facing because it exposes me to criticism. I've taken a risk by putting <a title="Face The Buzz Marketing " href="http://facethebuzz.com/blog" target="_blank">my business</a> on hold to learn to program. Aside from my own sense of pride in what I've accomplished, much of the value of this project is relying on me building a web app that others find value in.

It's an interesting paradox because each step I take in learning brings me closer to reaching my goal of building a working web app. But, until I've built anything, I'm also that much closer to failing.

At one point I considered adding a count-down clock to my site for dramatic effect. In a wise move, I opted out. Can you imagine having to stare at that every day? Talk about stress.

[caption id="attachment_448" align="aligncenter" width="500"]<a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/countdown-clock.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-448" title="Countdown Clock" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/countdown-clock.jpg" alt="Countdown Clock" width="500" height="241" /></a> Image courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/laughingsquid/4110317265/" target="_blank">Scott Beale</a>[/caption]
<h2>What's At Stake?</h2>
I'm trying to not to dwell too much on interpreting this project in a success vs. failure mindset. There are lot of great accomplishments simply in undertaking this journey.  However, when I reach the end of this 18 week journey, I'll have to face people and summarize this project and my outcome.

Many close friends and family have expressed admiration in my courage to take a chance in learning something new. But what about when I need to demonstrate a more concrete result. If I can't build a functioning app, will people respect my courage to try? Or will they look at me and think I took an 18 week siesta on the beach?

Certainly, I'm exposing myself by admitting these insecurities, but self-doubt is by no means isolated to me. Developers and others who seek to create something from scratch, such as artists, engineers, and designers, must also face this hurdle. In fact, some level of self-inflected stress can be beneficial.

In his book, "The 4-Hour Work Week", Tim Ferriss discusses how we can cultivate <strong><em>eustress</em></strong>, in which we have a positive cognitive response to stress. Harnessing these intrinsic emotional and chemical responses can be very powerful in propelling us towards an accomplishment.

When you have an important project, how do you harness stress and anxiety to overcome and achieve a successful outcome?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Learning to program and building an app can be stressful. How we can cultivate eustress to help in propelling us towards an accomplishment?  
]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>423</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-11-08 07:43:18</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>42</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Corey Freeman]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email></wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://twitter.com/CoreyFreeman</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>24.224.105.102</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2012-11-18 14:47:00</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2012-11-18 22:47:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I find I can't work well when I'm stressed out, so I have to find ways to work around the stress. One of my favorites is listening to film scores on Pandora (the online radio). Sometimes I go on a walk to check my mailbox. Sometimes I do pull-ups, and then sometimes I just take a nap. I think stress in coding is a build-up of typing in variations on code and watching it not work. You have to dig yourself out of the rut and put that energy into a new approach, which is usually stupidly simple.


Cool blog!]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Taking breaks is a great idea. My stress tends to build when I break code and/or can't build specific functionality; it definitely builds when I'm repeatedly unsuccessful. I tend to not stop at this point because I have this desire to fix it. 


However, that does tend to take me deeper and deeper. Perhaps, a mental break would help!]]></wp:comment_content>

However, that does tend to take me deeper and deeper. Perhaps, a mental break would help!]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Bob Roberts]]></wp:comment_author>

			<wp:comment_author_url>http://twitter.com/broberts_az</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>68.110.127.36</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2012-11-20 21:37:00</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2012-11-21 05:37:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[A lot of times I feel the stress/pressure when working on an app.  I am the type that does not give up until I figure it out which is a bad thing.  What I have found that helps is to change my focus on to something easier to do that requires less thinking.  A great byproduct to this is the fact that more time than not, after returning to the original issue, I figure it out quite fast.

Keep on learning!!!]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Good advice @twitter-199393780:disqus . There is a proven psychological benefit to successfully completing a task. I could see then how your approach to tackle something else and then return to the problem would refreshing!]]></wp:comment_content>
