	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Learning to Program Supporters</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/11/learning-to-program-supporters/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 21 Nov 2012 21:24:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=457</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>"It Takes A Village to Raise a Programmer" - <strong>I just made that up for this post.</strong></blockquote>
So yes I did fabricate this quote for my own purposes. But it seems to fit my situation well, as I truly have been the benefactor of tremendous support and efforts of many. And as those of us in the US settle into our annual time of thanks, I feel incredibly grateful to everyone who has shown me support.

Heading down this <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/">path to learn to program</a> required a strong leap of faith, and I don't regret it for one second. That's not to say it's been all positive; in between learning and building, there have been times of <a title="The Role of Stress in Learning to Program" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/11/stress-learning-to-program/">stress</a> and frustration.

But the support of everyone from family to complete strangers has been overwhelming. It's great to know there are people pulling for my success.
<h2>Tweet of Support</h2>
I've placed the following tweet on this site from the beginning. An amazing number of people, many strangers, have sent this tweet out to support me.
<blockquote>"I support @andrewkkirk on his journey to go from total noob to programmer in 18 weeks." <strong><a href="http://clicktotweet.com/uAbCx" target="_blank">&lt; Tweet This Message &gt;</a></strong></blockquote>
I send a big thank you to all of you that have taken time to support in one way or another. Theses gestures mean more to me than you could imagine.
<h2>The Importance of Sharing</h2>
Once I made the commitment to learning to program fulltime, I knew it would also be important to write throughout my entire process. My hope is that others will benefit through documenting my experiences, and even avoid certain pitfalls by avoiding my mistakes.

An additional result, which I didn't anticipate, is that I've reconnected with people who find out about my project from social media. For example, I recently received this note from a high school soccer coach I hadn't spoke to in several years.
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Support-Message.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-461" style="border: 2px solid grey;" title="Support Message" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Support-Message.png" alt="I just read most of your blogs on your page about learning to program. I wanted to let you know I am proud of you for taking this leap. Good luck and I know you have the determination and commitment to get it done. I look forward to hearing about your progress. Take care." width="495" height="233" /></a></p>
Isn't the internet incredible? Of course, if I hadn't written about my process and widely shared it, I wouldn't have had this benefit.
<h2>"On-Call" Support Team</h2>
Finally, I've add several people take time out of their busy schedules to support me by meeting up to pair program with me, discussing code on skype, and answering questions when I inevitably break something. These folks have gone above and beyond, all in the name of <a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/3-tips-help-learning-to-program/" target="_blank">helping a fellow developer</a>.
<ul>
	<li><a href="https://twitter.com/bostonsteamer" target="_blank">Joe Goldberg</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://twitter.com/whatcodecraves" target="_blank">Jerry Cheung</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twitter.com/ajsharp" target="_blank">Alex Sharp</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twitter.com/rails_apps" target="_blank">Daniel Kehoe</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://twitter.com/ruprictGeek" target="_blank">Glen Goodrich</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://twitter.com/panozzaj" target="_blank">Anthony Panozzo</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/how-developers-work/">Carbon Five Team</a></li>
</ul>
Remember to be thankful not just for those family and friends close to you, but also to those people that make a subtle impact on us. Without their support, I wouldn't have made it this far. Thank You!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[The support of everyone from family to complete strangers has been overwhelming. It's great to know there are people pulling for my success. And I feel incredibly grateful to everyone who has shown me support.]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>457</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-11-21 13:24:09</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-11-21 21:24:09</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>learning-to-program-supporters</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>46</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Joe Goldberg]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email></wp:comment_author_email>

			<wp:comment_author_IP>74.94.76.1</wp:comment_author_IP>

			<wp:comment_id>49</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Andrew K Kirk]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>andrew.k.kirk@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://andrewkkirk.com/</wp:comment_author_url>

			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>48</wp:comment_parent>

		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How I Got Unbanned from Hacker News</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/12/how-unbanned-from-hacker-news/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 03 Dec 2012 04:26:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=473</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote><em>Dear Internet Gods of Technology,</em>
<em> Forgive me for I have sinned.</em></blockquote>
Now that I've said my repentance, allow me to explain how I got my account unbanned from Hacker News.
<h2>Tech Sanctuary</h2>
For those who don't know, <a href="http://news.ycombinator.com/" target="_blank">Hacker News (HN)</a> is the Mecca of sharing all things nerd, tech, and science. Thousands of users go here daily to share the latest and greatest from the world of technology, computer engineering, and startups.

In addition to sharing, users can comment and vote-up articles, all of which can lead to your article landing on the coveted front page. There is great interest in it because a front page mention for your site can attract a large volume of traffic and expose your ideas or app to tens of thousands.

Like any popular system, it has attracted abusers. People looking to gain off the eyeballs of Hacker News, have submitted articles outside the scope of the site. Doing so, among other activities, can get you banned from the site.  But in the land of free accounts, this outcome is of little consequence to the user who can simply create new accounts ad nauseam.

As result, <a href="https://twitter.com/paulg" target="_blank">Paul Graham</a>, Venture Capitalist  Y Combinator co-founder, and HN administrator, has put in place an intelligent, and some would save devious, system for dealing with abusers: <a href="http://www.codinghorror.com/blog/2011/06/suspension-ban-or-hellban.html" target="_blank">hellbanning</a>. As a hellbanned user, you can continue to use the site as normal, but without other users seeing your submissions or comments.

Think of it this way: Basically, your Bill Cosby in "Ghost Dad" right after the car accident - everything feels and looks perfectly normal to you, but to the outside world of HN you're invisible. <strong>Nonexistent.</strong>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/ghost-dad.jpg"><img class="aligncenter  wp-image-477" title="ghost-dad" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/ghost-dad.jpg" alt="ghost-dad" width="384" height="230" /></a></p>

<h2>My Sins</h2>
How did this happen to me? It's pretty simple: I broke the HN rules. As a marketer, I signed up for HN and used it to submit articles I'd written for <a href="http://facethebuzz.com/blog" target="_blank">my blog or customers</a>. My posts were off-topic and I became hellbanned. I had no idea.

When I began my <a title="3 Steps to Create The Ultimate Plan to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/3-steps-create-plan-learn-code/" target="_blank">learning to program project</a>, I wanted to share my articles about learning programming as non-technical person. However, after a friend was unable to see <a href="http://news.ycombinator.com/submitted?id=andrewkkirk" target="_blank">my post on HN</a> and much searching, I realized that I was hellbanned.

I immediately felt embarrassed and bummed; I'm working to become actively involved in the developer community and here I was banned from one of it's most popular community sites. I had to make things right and get my account back.
<h2>Repairing The Damage Done</h2>
I discussed it with HN super user and<a href="http://railsapps.github.com/" target="_blank"> Rails Apps</a> creator <a href="http://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=DanielKehoe" target="_blank">Daniel Kehoe</a>. He's a really smart guy and incredily well-respected in both the Rails and HN communities. He kindly suggested I considered it a wash and create a new account.

But, I didn't think all hope was lost. The internet is supposed to bring us together, to connect us on a human-level, right? Couldn't I profess <em>mea culpa,</em> reform my behavior, and become a positive contributing member of HN?

So I found Paul Graham's email and sent him the following note:
<blockquote>Paul,

My account on HN news, <a href="http://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=andrewkkirk" target="_blank">andrewkkirk</a>, has been hellbanned. And rightfully so, I wasn't following the guidelines and submitting off-topic posts.

I've read the guidelines, understand the errors of my ways, and would now like to contribute in a positive manner to HN.

Other developers advised me to just create a new account, but I believe in the power of connecting personally and asking for a second chance.

Thanks in advance for the consideration,

Andrew Kirk</blockquote>
To my surprise, the following note landed in my inbox the following day:
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/paulgraham-email.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-495" style="border: 2px solid grey;" title="paul graham email" src="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/paulgraham-email.png" alt="paul graham email" width="402" height="198" /></a></p>

<h2>Lessons Learned</h2>
Clearly, I wish I hadn't have been banned in the first place. But, I did take away a few important lessons.
<h3>#1 Don't Abuse Sacred Communities</h3>
These communities are desirable because the collective value input by it's members. Abusing their standards devalues their work, angers community members, and puts you in a bad spot.
<h3>#2 Admit Wrongdoing; Ask for Forgiveness</h3>
It's not to say all wrongdoings will be forgiven. We should still act with decency. All to often online communities become outlets for free-range bad behavior.
<h3>#3 Make a Personal Connection</h3>
Our online worlds are bustling with social-integration and real-time communication. But, we can still lose sight of the personal aspects of the web. Don't let technology become a barrier to interacting on a personal level.
<h2>Unbanned from Hacker News Conclusion</h2>
I can only speculate as to why I was unbanned. I imagine Paul Graham responded to my honesty and appeal that people can correct mistakes. Or maybe anyone can get unbanned from Hacker News.

Leave your thoughts and questions in the comments below. Also, join the <a href="http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=4872844">discussion on Hacker News</a>.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I'm not sure whether it's a good or bad system; it's certainly a controversial system. On one hand, the community has the right to do what is necessary to keep out people who abuse the system. 


Bit. the problem that I see is that banning is based on getting down votes. Down votes can be for abuses, but they can also be for providing unpopular viewpoints. This setup dissuades users from providing dissenting viewpoints and can create a heard mentality.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_id>58</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Andrew K Kirk]]></wp:comment_author>

			<wp:comment_author_url>http://andrewkkirk.com/</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>75.85.53.62</wp:comment_author_IP>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2012-12-08 16:46:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[It's always a delicate balance in these types of communities. You don't want them to become spam-filled and overrun with self-promotion, but on other hand people want them to a place to promote their work. 
Inbound.org and hub.startuprev.com both have great balance of material.]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>My Most Helpful Materials in Learning to Program</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/12/learning-to-program-learning-materials/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 09 Dec 2012 02:08:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=503</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The number one question I receive about learning to program is which tools have been most helpful to me. It's an interesting and delicate question for me to answer, because usually the person is hoping to recreate my experience.

I intentionally made the title of this post in reference to my personal materials, as opposed to a generic "Best Tools for Learning to Program". While, the <a href="http://facethebuzz.com/blog" target="_blank">marketer in my brain</a> wanted to use this broader appealing title to attract a larger audience, it wouldn't have been has beneficial to you.

<strong>Learning styles</strong> vary and what works for me, won't necessarily work for the next.

In this regard, I've been careful to write about how to start the process learning to code and important factors to considered in your own personal choices. If you're just starting out, see these articles for information about getting started:
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/3-steps-create-plan-learn-code/" target="_blank">3 Steps to Create The Ultimate Plan to Learn Code</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/4-factors-choose-first-programming-language/" target="_blank">4 Factors Crucial for Choosing Your First Programming Language</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/10/how-measure-learn-to-code-progress/" target="_blank">How I Measure My Progress to Learn to Code</a></li>
</ul>
Once you've thought about your best approach, you'll begin to think about learning tools to help your process and your chosen language. My personal learning approach is entirely focused on building web applications. I'm not trying to be a scholar of Ruby. As a result, I having working knowledge of Ruby, but not necessarily a strong grasp of the language at this point.

Instead, I've used the Rails framework to build my application and then only learn aspects of Ruby specifically required to build the next feature. I didn't start out my learning to program process with this mentality.

When I started, I read a lot online from more experienced developers ranting about newbies only using Rails and not understanding Ruby. Well, that was not going to happen with me. I wasn't going to be one of those uniformed developers. So I mistakenly made it my goal to learn Ruby from the very start.

I went though material on Ruby basics and covered Procs, Lambdas, Modules, etc. And it gave me a much stronger understanding of Ruby, right? Wrong. I didn't absorb the Ruby material because I had no context in which to frame it.

Fortunately, I've taken an agile approach in learning to program. I quickly dropped the Ruby material and only focused on building an app, knowing that I may need to supplement my understanding of Ruby at a later time. These are the materials that helped me do that:
<h2>Best Rails Learning Material</h2>
<ul>
	<li>"Build a Simple Ruby on Rails App" on <a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/recommend/treehouse/">Treehouse</a></li>
	<li>Reading the <a href="http://guides.rubyonrails.org/getting_started.html">"Getting Started with Rails</a>" Ruby Guide</li>
	<li>"<a href="http://pragprog.com/book/rails4/agile-web-development-with-rails">Agile Web Development with Rails</a>" from the Pragmatic Bookshelf</li>
</ul>
<h2>Front-end (HTML, CSS, JavaScript)</h2>
<div>
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.codecademy.com/users/andrewkkirk" target="_blank">Codecademy</a> for basic HTML and CSS</li>
	<li>"Build a Simply RoR App" on <a href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/recommend/treehouse/">Treehouse</a> presents JavaScript and jQuery inside an actual app.</li>
</ul>
These materials have been most helpful during my first 6 weeks where I focused on tutorials, reading, and creating a baseline level of knowledge to begin building my app. In a future post, I share my materials which have been most helpful for building my first Ruby on Rails app.

<span style="font-size: x-small;">Featured image courtesy of <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/wfryer/2516648940/" target="_blank">Wesley Fryer</a></span>

</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[These tools have been most in learning to program. These materials have been most helpful during my first 6 weeks where I focused on tutorials, reading, and creating a baseline level of knowledge to begin building my app.]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:comment_id>59</wp:comment_id>

  I too learn better when I can see what is going on while I work, so working through an app project is very helpful. Keep up the great work!]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Hope for Non-CS Majors Learning to Program</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/12/no-computer-science-degree-learning-to-program/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Dec 2012 21:57:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=531</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I don't have a computer science (CS) nor engineering degree. I didn't drop out of college or skip it all together because I was buried in lines of code working away as a developer. It's the reality of my background.

As a result, I'm certain there are important technical aspects of software development that I don't understand. In fact, I would bet there are technical aspects of computers and programming that I don't even yet realize that I don't know about.

And the truth is that I'm okay with it. After starting to program, thoughts of being in over my head crept in. How could I possibly get my programming abilities to be equivalent to an entry-level developer? But that's no longer the case. I've come to terms with the fact that I'm a non-CS degree web programmer.
<h2>Are College Degrees All Hype?</h2>
There has been lots of noise the last few years about <a href="http://news.investors.com/ibd-editorials/112912-635127-bailout-danger-looms-as-student-debt-nears-1-trillion.htm?p=full" target="_blank">college debt</a> and people <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/02/fashion/saying-no-to-college.html" target="_blank">bucking the college trend</a> ("college is for suckers"). So you might think I'm better off. Well, don't take these stories as the almighty truth; in fact, you can chalk up the uncollege movement to PR fluff.

I'm not saying that this movement doesn't have valid arguments and dedicated, intelligent individuals working to disrupt an educational industry desperately in need of it. But, if you want to gain professional employment as a developer <em>today</em>, every job description will mention requirement of a CS degree or equivalent experience (EE). Perhaps employers in the future will catch up to speed with the trend away from college degrees, but not yet.

Interestingly, spending four years in school doesn't necessarily prepare you as a programmer on Day 1. The degree is often used as a 'stamp of approval' to indicate you're capable of learning new, complex material. Ultimately, your skills at development boil down to time invested in honing the craft.
<h2>Succeeding Without The CS Degree</h2>
A computer science degree will make it much easier to get your foot in the door with employers, but you can still do it without one. If you're in the same boat as me and a CS degree is not an option, you've got to take other avenues in order to gain more experience.
<h3>If You Build It, They Will Come</h3>
Nothing speaks louder about your abilities as developer than demonstrating the code you've created. Create your own apps and contribute to open source. It will enhance your abilities and open doors within the developer community.

Or you can go the route that <a href="https://twitter.com/bryanhelmig" target="_blank">Bryan Helmig</a> and the other <a href="https://zapier.com/app/about" target="_blank">Zapier cofounders</a> took. None of these guys have a CS degree, but they've built a budding SaaS business, gained customers, and were accepted and successfully completed YCombinator. Bryan's <a href="https://zapier.com/blog/2012/10/30/3-dudes-missouri-built-product-found-paying-customers-and-got-yc/" target="_blank">own words on the experience</a>  are worth the quick read.
<h3>Ignore Formal Job Descriptions</h3>
If running your own company is not your fit, there are still many great opportunities. If you're a self-taught programmer, than you're incredibly self-motivated and driven.To find an employer to hire you and give you experience, you're going to have to harness that same spirit.

Take that same drive and apply it to convincing a person to hire you. You're not going to woo anyone on paper with your resume; you're going to do it in person. Look for companies that are hiring entry-level engineers (&lt;2 years experience) and network with their current engineers using LinkedIn or better yet at local meetups. Also, look for companies with multiple open engineering positions; companies in need of talent will be more likely to place a bet on hiring you on the cheap in order to develop your skills further.
<h2>Non-CS Majors Learning to Program Conclusion</h2>
Whether you have a computer science degree or not, learning to program requires much hard work, determination, and perseverance. Be prepared that if you don't travel a traditional route, you'll need to hustle a little bit harder to create your career path.

<strong>UPDATE:</strong>  Join the <a href="http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=4953491" target="_blank">discussion on Hacker News.</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Learning to program requires much hard work, determination, and perseverance. If you don't have computer science (CS) degree, you'll need to make additional efforts to create your career path.]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>5 Great Books for Nerds Who Want to Learn about Game Programming</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2013/01/5-great-books-for-nerds-who-want-to-learn-about-game-programming/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 12 Jan 2013 22:55:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>myguestblog</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=542</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>It's been said that nerds are simply people who have strong interests. If you are a nerd and proud of it, and your strong interest happens to be game development, then you should be happy to know that there is a book market catering to nerds just like you. Want to know more about pursuing your passion? Here are five great books for nerds who want to learn about game programming:</p>
<p><strong>Beginning C++ Through Game Programming by Michael Dawson.</strong> Written with newbie programmers in mind, this text offers comprehensive, easy to understand instructions for learning the C++ programming language in step-by-step format. Build your knowledge and understanding as you go, by completing one project (per chapter) at a time.</p>
<p><strong>Game Engine Architecture by Jason Gregory.</strong> Intended as a textbook for college-level game programming classes, this book is chock-full of useful information covering a wide array of subjects. You don't have to have prior knowledge to benefit from the text, though. Game Engine Architecture is appropriate for nerds of all types, from home-based do-it-yourselfers to more experienced amateur programmers.</p>
<p><strong>The Game Maker's Apprentice: Game Development for Beginner's by Jacob Habgood.</strong> This book is exactly what it sounds like: a guide to game programming, for those who are just starting out and who are interested in learning how to create games using the Game Maker Tool and programming language. Written by a professional game programmer and developer of the Game Maker Tool, this informative guidebook also comes with a CD for easy reference.</p>
<p><strong>Super Scratch Programming Adventure: Learn to Program by Making Cool Games by The LEAD Project.</strong> Many experienced game programmers claim that Scratch is one of the easiest to learn and simplest to use programming languages there is, and this book is so easy to follow that even a kid could use it! In full comic book format, Super Scratch Programming Adventure leads readers through the fascinating world of programming, from basic terminology to the creation of a variety of game platform types.</p>
<p><strong>Programming Video Games for the Evil Genius by Ian Cinnamon.</strong> This book's author is a veteran game programmer, and you can put his vast knowledge to work for you by taking advantage of the text's many great features, from programming language how-to's to in-depth game creation strategies.</p>
<p>If you are interested in learning all you can about game programming, then you should be pleased to find that there is no shortage of great books for the self-motivated apprentice. No matter what your current skill level, you can be sure to find a lot of new knowledge to add to your database by drawing from these great resources.</p><p style='font-style: italic'><p><strong>About the Author:&nbsp;</strong>Pura Bouthillette loves to program her own software apps and games. She often works closely with <a href="http://allianceglobalservices.com/core/product-development-services">product development services</a> who need individuals skilled in creation and testing.</p></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>542</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-01-12 14:55:33</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-01-12 22:55:33</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>5-great-books-for-nerds-who-want-to-learn-about-game-programming</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>trash</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_linkdex</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[0]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_trash_meta_status</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[draft]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_trash_meta_time</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1368852164]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Digital Products And Services You Should Build For Your Business</title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2013/02/digital-products-and-services-you-should-build-for-your-business/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Feb 2013 11:06:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>myguestblog</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=544</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>It's old news now that any business should have a website, and really if you still don't have one then you are severely behind the times and in need of updating. But building a website alone isn't enough to completely modernise your organization and there are many different kinds of digital products and services that you should build for your site if you want to take full advantage of modern technology. Here we will look at the features you should add to your site and the other things you should develop that can help you to take full advantage of the web and the devices we use to explore it.</p>
<p><strong>Website</strong></p>
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/pleeker/151773521/"><img src="http://farm1.staticflickr.com/54/151773521_087be19909.jpg" alt="May 22, 2006: My First Laptop" width="500" height="375" /></a></p>
<p>First and foremost you should of course have a website, and this should be one that looks as professional as possible while at the same time offering all the features and information that your visitors need. You might have a website already, but you need to ask yourself whether it's representing your business the way you want it to.</p>
<p><strong>Blog</strong></p>
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/notionscapital/2493066577/"><img src="http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2138/2493066577_d1006bcec3.jpg" alt="Rosie the Blogger" width="386" height="451" /></a></p>
<p>Having a static website alone isn't really enough, even if your site is well designed. By adding a blog you give your business more transparency and make it more personal and this is a great way to communicate with your customers and let them know about new updates. It's also very good for your SEO as Google loves any site that is updated regularly.</p>
<p><strong>Store</strong></p>
<p>This may not be suitable for every business, but if you sell a product you should certainly consider giving your visitors the option to buy online. This makes buying your items easier and quicker, but once again also helps to make your business appear more modern and more up-to-date.</p>
<p><strong>Web Apps</strong></p>
<p>If you want to go above and beyond the competition, then a web app can be a great way to do so. Web apps are applications that run right in your browser and these can be used to add more function to your site or to provide more tailored information.</p>
<p><strong>Mobile Site</strong></p>
<p>All these features will enhance your company's 'web offering', but it's important to remember that a large proportion of your visitors these days won't <em>be </em>on a computer. This means they'll still be able to access your site, but will be doing so on a device with a smaller screen and perhaps a slower connection. To get around this issue, providing a mobile site will mean they see a different version of your web pages that is optimized for these smaller devices and that will give them a better user experience.</p>
<p><strong>Mobile Apps</strong></p>
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/marcopako/2873288743/"><img src="http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3212/2873288743_f3c0f4c6b6.jpg" alt="The best Apps for iPhone" width="320" height="480" /></a></p>
<p>If you want someone to have even quicker access to our information and to be able to interact with it in a more intuitive and rapid manner, then creating a mobile app is a great way to do this. This will be installed right on their device, but can link right into their browser and provide all the information. It's also a great way to increase your brand awareness and reach a wider audience.</p><h5>Attached Images:</h5><ul><li><img src='http://farm1.staticflickr.com/54/151773521_087be19909.jpg' style='width: auto' />&nbsp;<span class='license'>License: Creative Commons</span>&nbsp;<span class='source'><a target='_blank' href='http://www.flickr.com/photos/pleeker/151773521/'>image source</a></span>&nbsp;</li><li><img src='http://farm3.staticflickr.com/2138/2493066577_d1006bcec3.jpg' style='width: auto' />&nbsp;<span class='license'>License: Creative Commons</span>&nbsp;<span class='source'><a target='_blank' href='http://www.flickr.com/photos/notionscapital/2493066577/'>image source</a></span>&nbsp;</li><li><img src='http://farm4.staticflickr.com/3212/2873288743_f3c0f4c6b6.jpg' style='width: auto' />&nbsp;<span class='license'>License: Creative Commons</span>&nbsp;<span class='source'><a target='_blank' href='http://www.flickr.com/photos/marcopako/2873288743/'>image source</a></span>&nbsp;</li></ul><p style='font-style: italic'><p>Vadim Kirichenko&nbsp;is a senior software programmer at Business Media. He has headed many a web designing projects for his firm and also runs a coaching institute for <a href="http://www.businessmedia.ca/">web development in Toronto</a>.</p></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How I Landed a $65,000-a-year Programming Job Offer Learning to Code in 18 Weeks to Become a Full Time Developer </title>
		<link>http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=567</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.andrewkkirk.com/?p=567</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>TL;DR:</strong> Zero Programming<strong>.</strong> 127 days of intensive self-study and pair programming. $65,000 Jr. Programmer Job Offer.

On September 10, I began an <a title="Why I Quit My Job to Learn Code" href="http://www.andrewkkirk.com/2012/09/quit-my-job-learn-code/" target="_blank">adventure, a mission to teach myself to code</a>. I'd worked with many amazing startups and technology companies with a focus on sales and marketing. But, I wanted to do more, to build and be at the core of building a product.

Before I started my journey, I considered myself a very computer savvy, non-technical person. I understood the basics of the web, front-end design, and had run through a few Codecademy tutorials. But, I couldn't code up a web page, had never interacted with a database, nor understood

Why Full Time?

Click here to find out why I turned down the job.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
